natural problem: Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9?
natural solution: There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and B :: "int set"
and h0 : "card A = 6" and h1 : "card B = 6"
and h2 : "A = {1..6}" and h3 : "B = {1..6}"
and h4 : "prob_space (\<lambda>x. x \<in> A \<times> B)"
and h5 : "events = {e. \<exists>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a + b = e}"
shows  "prob {9} = 1/9"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and B :: "int set"
and h0 : "card A = 6" and h1 : "card B = 6"
and h2 : "A = {1..6}" and h3 : "B = {1..6}"
and h4 : "prob_space (\<lambda>x. x \<in> A \<times> B)"
and h5 : "events = {e. \<exists>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a + b = e}"
shows  "prob {9} = 1/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two sets A and B, each containing the integers from 1 to 6, and the probability space is defined on the Cartesian product of A and B. The event is defined as the sum of an element from A and an element from B. What is the probability that the sum is 9? The final answer is 1/9.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> prob x = 1/6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> prob (x+y) = prob x * prob y"
shows  "prob 9 = 1/9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> prob x = 1/6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> prob (x+y) = prob x * prob y"
shows  "prob 9 = 1/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a game with a standard six-sided die, the probability of any single outcome (1 through 6) is 1/6. If the outcomes of two dice rolls are added together, the probability of that sum is the product of the probabilities of the two rolls. What is the probability that the sum of two rolls is 9? The final answer is 1/9.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p (x + y) = p x * p y"
shows  "p 9 = 1 / 9"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p (x + y) = p x * p y"
shows  "p 9 = 1 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a function $p$ such that for all $x$ between 1 and 6 inclusive, $p(x) = \frac{1}{6}$. Also, for any $x$ and $y$ between 1 and 6 inclusive, $p(x + y) = p(x) \times p(y)$. What is the value of $p(9)$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{9}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> p i j = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>(i, j). p i j) {(i, j). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> i + j = 9} = 1 / 9"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> p i j = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>(i, j). p i j) {(i, j). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> i + j = 9} = 1 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Assume that a pair of fair six-sided dice are rolled and the probability of any particular outcome $(i, j)$, where $i$ and $j$ are the numbers on the first and second die respectively, is $\frac{1}{36}$. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the two dice is $9$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{9}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int set"
and prob :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "die1 = {1..6}"
and h1 : "die2 = {1..6}"
and h2 : "prob = (\<lambda>set. real (card set) / 36)"
shows  "prob {n + m |n m. n \<in> die1 \<and> m \<in> die2 \<and> n + m = 9} = 1 / 9"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int set"
and prob :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "die1 = {1..6}"
and h1 : "die2 = {1..6}"
and h2 : "prob = (\<lambda>set. real (card set) / 36)"
shows  "prob {n + m |n m. n \<in> die1 \<and> m \<in> die2 \<and> n + m = 9} = 1 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Two dice, each with sides numbered 1 through 6, are thrown. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the top faces of the dice is 9? The final answer is 1/9.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> A n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> B n = 1 / 6"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P n = A n * B (9 - n) + P (n-1)"
shows  "P 9 = 1 / 9"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> A n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> B n = 1 / 6"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P n = A n * B (9 - n) + P (n-1)"
shows  "P 9 = 1 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider two functions A and B, each defined from the integers to the integers, that are both equal to 1/6 for all integers n between 1 and 6. Now, let P be a function from the integers to the reals such that for every integer n between 1 and 6, P(n) equals the product of A(n) and B(9 - n) plus P(n - 1). Find P(9). The final answer is 1/9.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "real set" and event :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "die1 = {1..6}"
and h1 : "die2 = {1..6}"
and h2 : "event = {(x, y) . x in die1 and y in die2 and x + y = 9}"
shows  "measure (die1 \<times> die2) event = 1/9"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "real set" and event :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "die1 = {1..6}"
and h1 : "die2 = {1..6}"
and h2 : "event = {(x, y) . x in die1 and y in die2 and x + y = 9}"
shows  "measure (die1 \<times> die2) event = 1/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the two dice equals 9? The final answer is $\frac{1}{9}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {n. n \<le> 6 \<and> n \<ge> 1}"
and h1 : "prob_space p"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 6 \<and> n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> p n = 1/6"
and h3 : "prob p {n. \<exists>x y. x + y = n \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<and> x \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<ge> 1} = 1/9"
shows  "p 9 = 1/9"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {n. n \<le> 6 \<and> n \<ge> 1}"
and h1 : "prob_space p"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 6 \<and> n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> p n = 1/6"
and h3 : "prob p {n. \<exists>x y. x + y = n \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<and> x \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<ge> 1} = 1/9"
shows  "p 9 = 1/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assume we have a probability space defined by the function $p$. We are considering a finite set of natural numbers between 1 and 6, inclusive. Each of these numbers has a probability of $1/6$. The probability that the sum of any two numbers in this set equals 9 is $1/9$. What is the probability of getting 9? The final answer is $1/9$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p i = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i < 1 \<or> i > 6 \<longrightarrow> p i = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. if i + j = 9 then p i * p j else 0) = 1 / 9"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p i = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i < 1 \<or> i > 6 \<longrightarrow> p i = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. if i + j = 9 then p i * p j else 0) = 1 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A die is rolled twice. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the two dice equals 9? The final answer is $\frac{1}{9}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" and P :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "\<forall> a \<in> A. \<forall> b \<in> B. P {(a, b)} = 1/36"
and h3 : "P {(a, b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a + b = 9} = 1/9"
shows  "P {(a, b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a + b = 9} = 1/9"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability the sum rolled is 9? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are 4 different ways to roll a 9 (3+6, 4+5, 5+4, 6+3), which makes the probability of rolling a 9 equal to $\dfrac{4}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" and P :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "\<forall> a \<in> A. \<forall> b \<in> B. P {(a, b)} = 1/36"
and h3 : "P {(a, b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a + b = 9} = 1/9"
shows  "P {(a, b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a + b = 9} = 1/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If you have two sets A and B, both consisting of the integers from 1 to 6, and the probability of picking any pair (a, b) from A and B respectively is 1/36, then what is the probability of picking a pair (a, b) such that their sum is 9? The final answer is 1/9.
